item.title: [Itrfoundation] Order vs. Chaos in Immigration Enforcement
item.description:
Immigration enforcement is a federal responsibility that depends on local cooperation. Local officials are not meant to enforce immigration law themselves, but when they cooperate with federal authorities—by transferring custody after criminal cases are resolved—enforcement occurs quietly and efficiently, largely out of public view. When states or cities refuse to cooperate, enforcement becomes more visible and confrontational. Resistance by local officials forces federal agents to conduct arrests in public spaces, increasing disruption, political backlash, and the likelihood of protest. Iowa looks different because its laws require cooperation and respect for the rule of law. As a result, immigration enforcement in Iowa is more orderly, less chaotic, and far less likely to trigger public unrest, illustrating how leadership and legal structure shape real-world outcomes.

The post Order vs. Chaos in Immigration Enforcement appeared first on ITR Foundation.
